div.head: Chapter 4
div.p:
But some signs are natural, like smoke signifying fire, other are given
Augustinus, De doctrina christiana, II, c. n. 2 . And of those which are given, some are sacraments, and some are not. For every sacrament is a sign, but the reverse is not true.

The sacrament of something carries a likeness of the thing for which it is a sign.
For if the sacrament did not have a likeness of the things of which they are a sacrament, they would not properly be called sacraments.
Augustinus, epist. 98 Ad Bonifacium, n. 9 (PL 33, 364) . For something is properly called a sacrament which is a sign of the grace of God and a form of invisible grace, such that it carries the image of it and exists as its cause. Therefore the sacraments are instituted not only for the sake of signifying, but also for the sake of sanctifying.

For what has been instituted for the sake of signifying, are only signs, and not sacraments, just as there were carnal sacrifices and ceremonial observances of the old law, which were never able to make just those who were offering them, because, as the Apostle says,
the blood of goats and of oxen and the ashes of heifer sprinkled would be sanctifying the unclean for the cleansing of the flesh
Hebrews 9:13 , not of the soul, for this iniquity was the contact of death.

Whence Augustine:
I understand iniquity, which the law cleans, to be nothing other than the contact of the death of humanity, which whoever touched,
was unclean for seven days Numbers 19:11 , but was purified according to the law on the third and seventh, and was clean
Augustinus, Quaestionibus in Pentateuch, IV, q. 33 (PL 34, 735) , such that he may now enter the temple.

Now sometimes these laws were cleansing people from a bodily leprosy, but
no one was every justified from the works of the law , as the
Apostle
says, even if they do them in faith and love. Why? because God imposed them in servitude, not in justification, so that they would be figures of the future, that one might will these form himself rather than offering them to idols. These therefore are signs, and even sacraments, though often less properly named in scripture because they were signs of sacred things, which they by no means surpassed. But these things that the Apostle calls
works of the law Romans 3:20
are only instituted either for the sake of signifying or out of necessity.
